content.subtitle: Subject Positioning
text: The subject should be positioned in contralateral lateral decubitus (i.e., right side lying for examining the left greater trochanter, and vice versa)
The hip being examined should be in slight flexion, and a pillow can be placed between the subject's knees for comfort

content.subtitle: Anatomical Landmarks and Palpation
text: Locate and palpate the greater trochanter, which is the main bony prominence on the lateral aspect of the proximal thigh
To facilitate probe positioning, determine the anterior and posterior margins of the greater trochanter by palpation

vues.title: Transverse View
objectifs: Observation of the three facets of the greater trochanter and surrounding musculotendinous structures
positionnement: Place the probe in longitudinal view, almost parallel to the trunk, at the level of the anterior border of the greater trochanter
Moving the probe slightly distally (a few centimeters), rotate the probe slightly so that its proximal end is slightly posterior to its distal end (in this image, counterclockwise)
Again, move the probe slightly distally, then apply rotation in the same direction as before, to obtain an angle of approximately 45Â° with the trunk axis

text: The greater trochanter [GT] is a bony prominence of the proximal femur that serves as an attachment point for several pelvic girdle muscles. The GT is located on the lateral aspect of the femur and is a frequently used bony landmark during physical examination, postural assessment, or ultrasonographic examination.

The GT has three facets: anterior, middle, and posterior (or posterosuperior) facets. These facets primarily serve as insertion sites for two hip abductor muscles, namely the gluteus minimus and gluteus medius. The gluteus maximus, on the other hand, attaches more distally to the gluteal tuberosity of the femur and to the iliotibial tract[2].

Both trochanters (the GT and lesser trochanter) are extra-articular, meaning they are not covered by the structures that define the hip joint (primarily the joint capsule)[2]. The tensor fasciae latae is also associated with the GT, although it does not attach to it: given the origin-insertion axis of this muscle and the fact that it overlaps the anterolateral aspect of the GT, hip flexion-extension movements can cause sliding between these structures. For more information on this topic, see the clinical relevance section below.

content.subtitle: Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome [GTPS]
text: Ultrasound imaging is frequently used to evaluate subjects with bursopathy or tendinopathy in the greater trochanter region. Since it can be difficult to differentiate between these two types of pathologies based solely on clinical examination, they are sometimes grouped under the term 'greater trochanteric pain syndrome'[2].

This syndrome more commonly affects middle-aged women, who report acute pain in the posterolateral aspect of the greater trochanter, particularly during sleep and deep palpation, without presenting mobility limitations. The causes of this syndrome are not yet consensus in the scientific literature, although research seems to point toward the involvement of microtrauma leading to hip abductor tendon ruptures[4][5][15]. The emergence of this hypothesis would replace the pathophysiological mechanism that, until then, was considered most probable, i.e., trochanteric bursitis[2].

This syndrome is considered analogous to rotator cuff tendon tears, and as in the case of the shoulder, ultrasound imaging can be useful in demonstrating the presence of pathological changes within the gluteal muscle tendons[2]. However, the scientific literature regarding the usefulness of ultrasound in trochanteric pain syndrome currently relies mainly on lower quality articles (e.g., case studies), which explains why ultrasound is currently little used in this type of condition[11].

content.subtitle: Snapping Hip
text: The term 'snapping hip' refers to a condition characterized by hip pain accompanied by a snapping sound during hip movements (e.g., while walking). These signs and symptoms are not very specific and can therefore be associated with a large number of intra- or extra-articular pathologies[2].

content.subtitle: Internal: For more information on this topic, please consult the femoral neck protocol.
text: External: this type of phenomenon is often caused by friction (or impingement) of the iliotibial band on the greater trochanter and is associated with symptomatology very similar to snapping caused by the iliopsoas tendon (see the femoral neck protocol on this topic). The clinical presentation of external cases is mainly differentiated by the presence of referred pain to the lateral aspect of the hip, although subjects may also be completely asymptomatic. The movements associated with symptoms are as follows: a hip in extension and adduction moved into flexion and external rotation with the knee flexed. [2]
